School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering the Key Laboratory of Environment-friendly Polymer Materials of Anhui Province & Key Laboratory of Structure and Functional Regulation of Hybrid Materials (Anhui University) Ministry of Education Hefei 230601 PR China The cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide (PO) is of great significance to green chemistry and resource utilization. Here, two new metal clusters and four ruthenium photosensitizers were synthesized, and a series of composite catalysts were prepared by combining them with cobalt phthalocyanine. Light was introduced into the reaction system and it was found that TON increased from 550 (0 W) to 990 (200 W) at 60 °C. At 120 °C, 200 W, the TON was as high as 4616. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) experiments showed that for the Cat13, electrons were generated by light irradiation. After the system was injected into PO, the photogenerated electrons quickly transferred to PO. Gibbs free energy calculations also indicate that by introducing light, the system is more likely to promote PO ring opening and exhibits excellent catalytic performance for CO2 ring addition. In addition, the recycled catalyst can still catalyze the formation of propylene carbonate from CO2 and PO. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal clusters Ruthenium photosensitizer Photocatalysis cycloaddition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Due to industrialization, the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has extremely increased, leading to the greenhouse effect, the glaciers melt and sea levels rised [1]. At the same time carbon dioxide can be used as a promising C1 source for the manufacture of fuels, carbonates, polymers and chemicals. The cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides is considered an effective waste-to-energy method that uses CO2 as a precursor to produce a variety of valuable cyclic carbonates at 100 % of the atom utilization [2]. Wherein, propylene carbonate (PC) generated by the cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide (PO) is a non-toxic and low odor solvent, commonly used as an intermediate in organic synthesis and an electrolyte for lithium-ion batteries, which is of great significance [3–5]. The cycloaddition of CO2 and PO to produce PC is a thermodynamically demanding process that requires high temperatures and pressure. In recent years, photocatalysis has become a popular field. Introducing light to drive the reaction system can break the thermodynamic limitations and thus improve the catalytic performance. Some scientists use light to assist the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to generate cyclic carbonates, allowing the reaction to proceed under mild conditions [6–9]. Terpyridine ligand as one of the most effective ligands, have high potential in photocatalytic applications and demonstrates exceptional stability and photochemical capabilities in coordinating with low valence metals [10]. Among them, divalent ruthenium and terpyridine coordination are classical photosensitizers due to their excellent visible light trapping ability and high electron transfer efficiency [11–15]. Chlorophyll, whose active center is magnesium porphyrin, can catalyze the conversion of CO2 into carbohydrates in plants. Some researchers have looked into metal phthalocyanine compounds having a structure similar to porphyrin to catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 and PO [16,17]. Jiawei Wang [18] using the coordinate covalent bond, showed that when pyridine was coupled with iridium photosensitizer, N of pyridine and Co in the phthalocyanine center synergistically reduced CO2. This dynamic coordination interaction can provide a previously unexplored pathway for photocatalytic CO2 and PO cycloaddition (Fig. 1 ). Catalysts play an important role in photocatalytic reaction systems, and a photocatalyst usually consists of two parts. (1) the light-responsive part, which captures and utilizes light, and (2) the active part, which is used as the active site to promote the reaction to take place. The development of efficient catalytic systems for the conversion of CO2 into the desired cyclic carbonate plays a key role in the utilization of CO2. The combination of metal sites (Lewis acids) and nucleophilic reagents can synergistically catalyze the cyclization reaction of CO2, resulting in high activity, and therefore a variety of metal-based catalysts, including metal complexes and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), have been established [19–32]. Metal catalysts have progressed in recent years from single atoms to metal nanoparticle and metal nanoclusters, with metal clusters emerging as the preferred form for many reactions due to their distinct structural advantages, high selectivity, and activity [31,33-35]. Jiapeng Cao [24] prepared four heterogeneous clusters catalysts with TBAB as co-catalyst. The final yield of PC cycloaddition of CO2 and PO was >99 % at the reaction temperature of 70 °C, CO2 pressure of 0.5 MPa and reaction time of 16 h. Caiyun Liu [9] reported a novel Ti-Bi mixed metal oxide cluster Ti18Bi4O29Bz26, which has high photocatalytic activity and selectivity for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxide, allowing the reaction to proceed under mild conditions. In summary, metal clusters have notable benefits over traditional catalysts in the field of catalysis. Metal nanoclusters have small-scale effects and more surface active sites, which have a certain number of constituent atoms and structures. Their electronic energy band structures can be flexibly controlled by chemical composition and geometry, and these advantages are more favorable for reactant contact and catalyst modification [36]. Therefore, how to make full use of these advantages and develop new metal cluster catalysts is of great importance for CO2 catalysis. In this study, two novel metal nanoclusters and four different ruthenium photosensitizers were synthesized for the first time, and thirteen composite catalysts were prepared by combining them with cobalt phthalocyanine (Table 1 ). The catalytic efficiency of these catalysts for photocatalytic CO2 and PO cycloaddition were investigated at specific wavelengths of visible light. The catalytic mechanism was elucidated. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization First, the terpyridine ligands were synthesized by a one-pot boiling method in potassium hydroxide solution with Michael addition to aromatic aldehydes and 2-acetylpyridine at specific temperatures, and the ring was combined under ammonia conditions to form terpyridine. Binding of the terpyridine ligand to RuCl3·3H2O and reduction from Ru3+ to Ru2+ under triethylamine reductant conditions to form a ruthenium photosensitizer (Scheme 1 ). Characterization data for compounds L1-L4 and PS1-PS3 are presented in the supporting literature (Fig. S1∼Fig. S7). In addition, UV-vis absorption tests were performed for the ruthenium photosensitizers, showing strong absorption peaks in the visible range (Fig. 2 ). Here, two newly obtained nanoclusters, Mn11.97 (T1) (11.97 is the problem of manganese atom occupancy in clusters) and Mn2Fe4 (T2), were synthesized. Cluster T1 was formed as a dimeric metal skeleton with two Mn6O6 metal skeletons through two acetonitrile molecules and pivalic acid and ethyl acetate as protecting groups for the metal atoms. Cluster T1 was synthesized by the reaction of pivalic acid, Bun 4NMnO4, and Mn (CH3CO2)2·4H2O in boiling acetonitrile in a 40:1:1 molar ratio. Brown crystals were formed at −5 °C and further recrystallized in a mixture of CH3COOC2H5:CH3CN (8:1) to form the final product of cluster T1 [Mn11.97O4(ButCO2)20(C4H8O2)6(CH3CN)2]. The crystal structure and metal nuclei of T1 are shown in Fig. 3 . Cluster T2 is a Mn2Fe4O6 metal skeleton with Mn atoms in the center of the cluster, Fe atoms at the periphery, and pivalic acid and pyridine as protecting groups for the metal atoms. The cluster was synthesized by the reaction of pivalic acid, Bun 4NMnO4, and Fe(CH3CO2)2·H2O in a molar ratio of 20:1:2 in boiling acetonitrile. Brown crystals were formed at −5 °C and further recrystallized in an ethyl acetate solution in the presence of 2 % pyridine to form the final product of Cluster T2 [Mn4Fe2O2(ButCO2)10(C5H5N)4]. The crystal structure and metal nuclei of Cluster T2 are shown in Fig. 3. 2.2 UV visible light absorption test The visible light absorption wavelengths of the thirteen composite catalysts were investigated by UV-visible tests. From Fig. 4 , it can be seen that the maximum absorption wavelengths of Cat1 and Cat2 are 658 nm and 678 nm. The Cat3 and Cat4 have no maximum absorption peaks in the whole visible light range, and the maximum absorption peaks of Cat5-Cat13 are around 500 nm. The maximum absorption peaks of the Cat5-Cat13 were due to the ruthenium photosensitizer, even with the addition of the two clusters and two cobalt phthalocyanine, there was no significant change in the position and intensity of the absorption peak. This phenomenon indicates that the addition of cluster T1, T2 and cobalt phthalocyanine does not affect the light absorption ability of ruthenium photosensitizers, which have good light absorption stability. When conducting photocatalysis, the maximum absorption peak of visible light was selected. 2.3 Catalytic cycloaddition reaction The cycloaddition of CO2 and PO is carried out in a autoclave under light and at a specific temperature. The obtained product was subjected to 1H-NMR analysis, and in the 1H-NMR spectrum of the product, the characteristic peak of PC was 1H-NMR (CDCl3), δ (ppm)1.49 (3H; CH3); 4.03 (1H; CH2); 4.56 (1H;CH2) and 4.86 (1H; CH). The peak values of polypropylene ether (PPO) were δ (ppm)1.16 (3H; CH3), 3.58 (2H; CH2), and 3.45 (1H; CH). The TON value of the catalytic product is calculated by the following equation: TON = m 1 100 M 2 m 2 m1: Quality of cycloaddition products; m2: catalyst quality; M2: molar mass of catalyst; 100 is the molar mass of a cycloaddition unit (per mole of cycloaddition unit has 1 mol of PO). To better understand the catalytic effectiveness, the catalytic performance of the catalysts was first examined at 60 °C, with a CO2 pressure of 2 MPa and 0 W (no light), and tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) was used as a co-catalyst. Interestingly, when the catalyst and TBAB work together, no additional by-products were observed in the catalytic products, indicating 100 % selectivity for PC. When only the Cat13 or TBAB was present in the system, 1H-NMR analysis indicated that in the product, the PPO was found with PC content only 57 % and 27 %, respectively (Figure S10). This phenomenon suggests that jointing the catalyst and co-catalyst are necessary for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction, which is consistent with other reports [9,37]. In the two phthalocyanine catalysts, COPC is less efficient than COTNPC in catalysis. The nitro group is an electron-absorbing group, resulting in a lower electron cloud density of the central Co ion, which exhibits a stronger charge affinity and more readily attracts electrons from the oxygen atom of the PO, making the CO bond more prone to break (Table 2 , entry 1 and 2). The Co atom in the center of COTNPC can form a dynamic coordination with the N atom of pyridine of ruthenium photosensitizer ligand [18]. Since PS4 contains a pyridine group at both ends, the pyridine group is an electron-absorbing group, leading to a decrease in the density of the Co electron cloud and further breaking the CO bond of PO. In previous studies, it was shown that pyridine is a basic group and the N of pyridine not only has a certain adsorption effect on CO2, but also acts as a nucleophilic reagent to attack PO and promote cyclization [38]. Therefore, the TON value increased after adding PS4 to COTNPC (Table 2, entry 2 and 9). To further understand the mechanism of the interaction between COTNPC and PS4, the structures of COTNPC and Cat9 using density-functional theory (DFT) by executing the B3LYP/6-31G(d) method on the Gaussian 09 program are optimized. The optimized structures of COTNPC and Cat9 and the corresponding orbital electron distributions are shown in Fig. 5 . As shown in Fig. 5A, the structures of COTNPC and Cat9 according to molecular modeling showed that the pyridines N of PS4 and Co of COTNPC were connected by NCo coordination bonds. As shown in Fig. 5B,C, there are significant variations in LUMO, HOMO, and ΔE. The results of DFT also indicate the possibility that pyridine N of PS4 and Co of COTNPC can form dynamic coordination bonds. Both metal cluster catalysts can catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 and PO. This may be that cluster T2 is surrounded by four pyridines, while cluster T1 is surrounded by valproates. Compared to valproates, four pyridines are more likely to cause cluster T2 to absorb electrons from the oxygen of PO and break the CO bond (Table 2, entry 3 and 4). It is worth mentioning that all thirteen composite catalysts can catalyze the formation of PC from CO2 and PO to obtain higher TON, and the results are shown in Table 3 . It can be seen that the TON increases obviously under light. For Cat13, it is clear that the TON increases significantly with the introduction of an external light source. The TON increases from 550 with 0 W to 990 with 200 W, almost double that of the TON obtained without light irradiation. 1H-NMR analysis of these products was performed for 0 W, 100 W, and 200 W, and no additional by-products were observed (Fig. S11). The catalytic efficiency of Cat13 was investigated at 90 ℃, 120 ℃ under 200 W light condition. At 200 W, 120 ℃, the TON is up to 4616, and Cat13 showed good photothermal synergy. By comparing the results of related studies on the synthesis of PC from immobilized CO2 in recent years, Cat13 has the best catalytic effect and potential applications (Table 4 ). 2.4 Mechanism of cycloaddition reaction The mechanism of cyclization of CO2 and PO into PC is thought to be based on the catalysis of metal sites (Lewis acids) [24,39,40]. As shown in Scheme 2 , Firstly, ring opening is activated by binding the oxygen atoms of PO to metal sites. Then TBAB uses its Br− as a nucleophilic reagent to attack carbon atoms on methylene, opening the epoxy ring. Then, the opened epoxide ring interacts with carbon dioxide to form carbonate anions. Finally, it is converted into a PC through a closed-loop step, while recycling TBAB. To further understand whether COTNPC, PS4, and cluster T2 exhibit synergistic effects under illumination, the chemical states and binding energies of the clusters T2, Cat9, and Cat13 after the photocatalytic cycloaddition reaction were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 6 (A) shows the XPS spectra of Mn2p. Compared with the metals Mn2p1/2 (653.4 eV) and Mn2p3/2 (641.7 eV) in cluster T2, the peaks of Mn2p1/3 and Mn2p2/3 in Cat13 are positively shifted by about 0.1 eV. Similarly, Fig. 6(B) shows that the peaks of Fe2p in Cat13 are positively shifted by about 0.4 eV. Fig. 6(C), the N1s (402.45 eV) in Cat13 are positively shifted by about 0.2 eV compared to the N1s (402.25 eV) in cluster T2. Compared with the N1s (398.55 eV) in Cat9, the corresponding N1s (398.75 eV) of the Cat13 is positively shifted by about 0.2 eV. This phenomenon is attributed to the strong electron effect arising from the synergistic interaction between COTNPC, PS4 and T2, and they can transfer electron to each other. The electronic effect between different elements helps to improve the photocatalytic performance. Through electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) experiments, the electrons excitation by Cat13 under light irradiation was examined. 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-yloxy (TEMPO), which does not normally react with active oxygen and electron holes, was introduced as an electron trapping agent in the test system. The EPR spectrum showed the absorption peak of TEMPO in dark (Fig. 7 A). No change in EPR intensity was observed after the addition of Cat13 under dark, demonstrating that no additional free electrons were generated in the dark. However, the EPR intensity decreased significantly after light irradiation (Fig. 7B). It may be that electron generated by light irradiation transfer to TEMPO (paramagnetic) to form TEMPOH (diamagnetic) which can decrease the intensity of EPR peak, this strongly proves that light irradiation does generate electrons. In the EPR test, the EPR intensity of TEMPO under light irradiation did not change when the system was injected with CO2 (Fig. 7C), indicating that photogenerated electrons could not be transferred to CO2. On the contrary, the EPR intensity of TEMPO under light irradiation increased when PO was injected into the system (Fig. 7D), indicating that photogenerated electrons can be transferred to PO rapidly. It can be seen from EPR test that compared with other photocatalysts for CO2 Cycloaddition reaction [9,40,41], the catalyst prepared in this paper can transfer photogenerated Electron transfer to PO to activate PO instead of reducing CO2 to free radical anion (CO2 •−). In a previous report, it was demonstrated that the open-loop step of the adsorption epoxide (Scheme 2I) is the rate-limiting step [42,43]. The ring opening potential of PO in dark and light environments was compared (Fig. 8 ) to understand the effect of excited electrons on ring opening. The reaction process under dark conditions is initialized by the attack of Br− on PO to form intermediate-1(see Fig. 8 black path), the Gibbs free energy is 53.24 Kcal/mol. At the point of maximum energy intermediate-1(see Fig. 8 black path), Br− near the C atom of CH2 , and needs to absorb 5.02 Kcal/mol to reach the transition state (see Fig. 8 black path), and after overcoming the COC bond energy of PO, two new bonds, CBr and CH, are formed, and releases 28.71 Kcal/mol to form the ring-opening end product. Instead, the introduction of light initialize PO to form the negatively charged intermediate-2 (see Fig. 8 for the orange pathway) by the producing electrons into the system, which needs an Gibbs free energy of 65.09 Kcal/mol, and the increase in energy is sufficient to supplement the energy cost for the PO open-loop step. Therefore, when the Br− is close to the C atom of CH2 , it does not need to absorb additional energy to reach transition state (see Fig. 8 for the orange pathway), and the COC bond of PO is more easily broken, leading to ring opening reactions and improved catalytic efficiency. Compared with dark conditions, the systems introducing light are more easily to stimulate PO opening and exhibit excellent catalytic performance for CO2 ring addition. 2.5 Recyclability of catalysts The repeatability of catalysts was examined because the recoverability is crucial for lowering manufacturing costs. As an example, Cat13 was subjected to five consecutive cycles under 200 W, 120 ℃ photocatalytic cycloaddition reaction. The co-catalyst TBAB was re-added for each cycling experiment. Calculate the TON for each cycle experiment, and the TON in the five cycle experiments are almost the same (Fig. 9 A). In addition, 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR analyses were performed for the fifth recycled product. The 1H-NMR spectrum is presented in Fig. 9B. The methyl protons appeared as a doublet at 1.44 ppm. Two doublet peaks appeared at 3.98 and 4.52 ppm, respectively, which refer to the methylene (CH2) protons. The multiple centered at 4.82 ppm corresponds to the CH proton, which is coupled to the methyl and methylene hydrogens. 1H-NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): 1.40–1.50 (dd, J = 6.4 Hz, 3H); 3.92–4.01 (dd, J = 7.8 Hz, 1H); 4.50–4.55 (m, J = 8.1 Hz, 1H); 4.80–4.90 (m, J = 6.6 Hz, 1H). The 13C-NMR spectrum is shown in Fig. 9C. The peak at 19 ppm is assigned to primary carbon (CH3). The peak at 71 ppm corresponds to the secondary (CH2) carbon, and the peak at 74 ppm corresponds to the primary (CH) carbon. Finally, carbonyl carbon appears at 155 ppm. 13C-NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3): 19, 71, 74, 155. As shown by 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR analysis, no new byproducts were found during the catalytic cycle process, and PC production has still 100 % selectivity. The recovery experiment shows that the recovered catalyst can still catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and PO, and the activity of the catalyst has no obvious loss. 3 Experimental section 3.1 Chemicals Acetonitrile and PO was purified by distillation over CaH2. DMF was first dried with anhydrous magnesium sulfate for more than 24 h before adding the 4A molecular sieves. Others organic solvents were dried using 4A molecular sieves. Cobalt phthalocyanine (COPC, 96 %) was purchased from Bide Pharmaceuticals. Nitro cobalt phthalocyanine (COTNPC) [44] and Bun 4NMnO4 [45] were synthesized according to the literature method. 3.1.1 Synthesis of compound L1 The synthesis steps of L1 ligand have been reported in other articles [46], and the synthesis steps in this article have been slightly modified. Nitrogen was passed throughout, in a 250 mL flask, 1-(4-(4-pyridyl)benzaldehyde 1.83 g (10 mmol), 2-acetyl pyridine 2.42 g (20 mmol) and 100 mL of ethanol were added and stirred for 15 min, after adding KOH solid 3.08 g (10 mmol) and stirring for 10 min, 30 mL of ammonia (30 %) was added with stirring at 40 °C for 4 h, and the solution was cooled to room temperature, a white solid was precipitated, filtered by extraction, washed with cold ethanol (5 mL×5), and the crude product was recrystallized in ethanol. Colorless crystals were obtained with a yield of 75 %. 1 H-NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6) δ 8.75 (d, J = 3.2 Hz, 4H), 8.70 – 8.62 (m, 4H), 8.07 (t, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 8.04 – 7.97 (dd, 4H), 7.82 – 7.75 (d, 2H), 7.54 – 7.47 (t, 2H). LC-MS : m/z calculated for C26H18N4 ([M+H]+) 387.15; found 387.1634 (Fig. S1). 3.1.2 Synthesis of compound L2 The synthesis steps of L2 ligand have been reported in other articles [47], and the synthesis steps in this article have been slightly modified. Nitrogen was passed throughout the process, 3.08 g (10 mmol) of potassium hydroxide solid was added into a three-necked flask containing 150 mL of ethanol, and after all dissolved, 1.36 g (20 mmol) of p-methoxybenzaldehyde and 1.21 g (40 mmol) of 2-acetyl pyridine were added together and stirred for 15 min, then 6 ml (30 %) of ammonia was added into the reaction flask and refluxed at 80 °C for 24 h. The solution was cooled and a green solid was precipitated. The solid was extracted and filtered, followed by washing with (5×10 mL) H2O and ice ethanol. The crude product was recrystallized in ethanol to give a white solid. The yield was 68 %. 1H-NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3-d) δ 8.72 (d, J = 5.0, 1.5 Hz, 2H), 8.70 (s, 2H), 7.87 (m, J = 8.8, 6.6 Hz, 4H), 7.38 – 7.31 (t, 2H), 7.06 – 6.99 (d, 2H), 3.87 (s, 3H). LC-MS:m/z calculated for C22H17N3O ([M+H]+): 340.1413; found 340.1458 (Fig. S2). 3.1.3 Synthesis of compound L3 Nitrogen was passed throughout and 1.06 g (40 mmol) of benzaldehyde, 2.42 g (80 mmol) of acetyl pyridine, 3.08 g (10 mmol) of potassium hydroxide, 30 mL (30 %) of ammonia and 100 mL of ethanol were added to a 250 mL flask and stirred well at 0 °C. The mixed solution was slowly warmed up and refluxed for 10 h. The solution was cooled to room temperature, and a green precipitate was extracted and filtered. The precipitate was washed with water and cold ethanol, after which it was recrystallized in ethanol to obtain a green solid. Adding the catalyst into the autoclave, and drying at 60 ℃ for 12 h. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature, PO was injected into the autoclave with a syringe. 2 MPa carbon dioxide was introduced into the autoclave, and then heated to a predetermined temperature by stirring. When the reaction reaches a predetermined time, the reaction system is cooled to room temperature. Before opening the autoclave, slowly discharge carbon dioxide from the autoclave. The reaction mixture was filtered through a silica gel pad to remove catalyst residues. The product is dried in a vacuum oven to a constant weight. For the photoblocking experiment, an opaque black cloth was used to cover quartz glass. In the photocatalytic experiment, an external light source was introduced and an incandescent lamp was used for illumination. The distance between the light source and the reactor quartz glass is 20 cm. Other wavelengths are filtered by the filter to obtain wavelengths around 500 nm (±18 nm; transmittance >90 %) (Fig. S12). 4 Conclusions Here, two new metal cluster catalysts and four ruthenium photosensitizers were synthesized. The UV-visible light test shows that the ruthenium photosensitizers have good light absorption stability, and the maximum absorption peaks of Cat5-Cat13 are all around 500 nm. The catalytic efficiency of cluster T2 is higher than that of cluster T1. The cycloaddition results indicate that the introduction of visible light significantly promotes catalytic efficiency. For Cat13, compared to the no light experiment, the catalytic efficiency increased from TON 550 of 0 W to TON 990 of 200 W at 60 ℃. And further increase the temperature to 120 ℃, the TON reaches 4616 at 200 W. The cyclic recovery showed that even after 5 cycles, the catalytic efficiency did not significantly decrease. The EPR experiment shows that for the Cat13, electrons are generated by light irradiation. After the system injects PO, photo generated electrons quickly transfer to the PO. Gibbs free energy calculations also demonstrate that by introducing light, the system better promotes PO ring opening and exhibits excellent catalytic performance for CO2 ring addition. coredata.dc:description: The cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide (PO) is of great significance to green chemistry and resource utilization. Here, two new metal clusters and four ruthenium photosensitizers were synthesized, and a series of composite catalysts were prepared by combining them with cobalt phthalocyanine. Light was introduced into the reaction system and it was found that TON increased from 550 (0 W) to 990 (200 W) at 60 °C. At 120 °C, 200 W, the TON was as high as 4616. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) experiments showed that for the Cat13, electrons were generated by light irradiation. After the system was injected into PO, the photogenerated electrons quickly transferred to PO. Gibbs free energy calculations also indicate that by introducing light, the system is more likely to promote PO ring opening and exhibits excellent catalytic performance for CO2 ring addition. In addition, the recycled catalyst can still catalyze the formation of propylene carbonate from CO2 and PO.
coredata.dc:title: Metal cluster/ruthenium photosensitizer/cobalt phthalocyanine synergistic photocatalytic cycloaddition of carbon dioxide and propylene oxide
